articles.headline: Alphabet Settles Shareholder Suits Over Sexual Harassment Claims
articles.snippet: Google’s parent company was hit with a wave of lawsuits after The New York Times reported that an accused executive had received a $90 million exit package.
articles.abstract: Google’s parent company was hit with a wave of lawsuits after The New York Times reported that an accused executive had received a $90 million exit package.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google’s parent company, Alphabet, has settled a series of shareholder lawsuits over its handling of sexual harassment claims, agreeing to greater oversight by its board of directors in future cases of sexual misconduct and committing to spend $310 million over the next decade on corporate diversity programs.

articles.headline: The Quiet 2013 Lunch That Could Have Altered Supreme Court History
articles.snippet: President Obama met with Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, hinting at retirement, but the art of nudging justices off the court is politically delicate and psychologically complicated.
articles.abstract: President Obama met with Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, hinting at retirement, but the art of nudging justices off the court is politically delicate and psychologically complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg joined President Barack Obama for lunch in his private dining room in July 2013, the White House sought to keep the event quiet — the meeting called for discretion.
articles.byline: By Susan Dominus and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Trump Selects Amy Coney Barrett to Fill Ginsburg’s Seat on the Supreme Court
articles.snippet: The president’s nomination of Judge Barrett, a favorite of conservatives, to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, will kick off a furious and unprecedented scramble to confirm her in the Senate before Election Day.
articles.abstract: The president’s nomination of Judge Barrett, a favorite of conservatives, to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, will kick off a furious and unprecedented scramble to confirm her in the Senate before Election Day.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Barr’s Approach Closes Gap Between Justice Dept. and White House
articles.snippet: The attorney general has brought the department closer to the White House than it has been in a half-century, historians said.
articles.abstract: The attorney general has brought the department closer to the White House than it has been in a half-century, historians said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the top federal prosecutor in Washington recently accused the local police of arresting protesters without probable cause, Attorney General William P. Barr stepped in.

articles.headline: Japan Is Paying Firms to Make Things at Home. But China’s Pull Is Still Strong.
articles.snippet: Japan is attempting a delicate balancing act as the pandemic has underlined the risks of the world’s economic reliance on Beijing.
articles.abstract: Japan is attempting a delicate balancing act as the pandemic has underlined the risks of the world’s economic reliance on Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Until July, the Japanese household goods company Iris Ohyama had always made its line of masks at its two factories in China.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Makiko Inoue

articles.headline: China Gives Unproven Covid-19 Vaccines to Thousands, With Risks Unknown
articles.snippet: Drug company workers, government officials and others have been injected outside the usual testing process. More will be soon, bewildering experts who worry about potential ill effects.
articles.abstract: Drug company workers, government officials and others have been injected outside the usual testing process. More will be soon, bewildering experts who worry about potential ill effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: First, workers at state-owned companies got dosed. Then government officials and vaccine company staff. Up next: teachers, supermarket employees and people traveling to risky areas abroad.

articles.headline: Inside eBay’s Cockroach Cult: The Ghastly Story of a Stalking Scandal
articles.snippet: “People are basically good” was eBay’s founding principle. But in the deranged summer of 2019, prosecutors say, a campaign to terrorize a blogger crawled out of a dark place in the corporate soul.
articles.abstract: “People are basically good” was eBay’s founding principle. But in the deranged summer of 2019, prosecutors say, a campaign to terrorize a blogger crawled out of a dark place in the corporate soul.
articles.lead_paragraph: Veronica Zea is pretty sure that before showing up to work at eBay in the spring of 2017, she used the site only once. She bought a surfing poster. It ended up in her closet.

articles.headline: How a Pledge to Dismantle the Minneapolis Police Collapsed
articles.snippet: When a majority of City Council members promised to “end policing as we know it” after George Floyd’s killing, they became a case study in how idealistic calls for structural change can falter.
articles.abstract: When a majority of City Council members promised to “end policing as we know it” after George Floyd’s killing, they became a case study in how idealistic calls for structural change can falter.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Over three months ago, a majority of the Minneapolis City Council pledged to defund the city’s police department, making a powerful statement that reverberated across the country. It shook up Capitol Hill and the presidential race, shocked residents, delighted activists and changed the trajectory of efforts to overhaul the police during a crucial window of tumult and political opportunity.

articles.headline: A High-Stakes Test for Joe Biden’s Love of Senate Tradition
articles.snippet: He reveres custom and recognizes the courts’ essential role in shaping a policy agenda. Those dual instincts have perhaps never been in greater conflict as they are in this Supreme Court fight.
articles.abstract: He reveres custom and recognizes the courts’ essential role in shaping a policy agenda. Those dual instincts have perhaps never been in greater conflict as they are in this Supreme Court fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. was trying to demonstrate the lasting power of the federal judiciary. So he did the math.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer, Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: Pasta, Wine and Inflatable Pools: How Amazon Conquered Italy in the Pandemic
articles.snippet: The e-commerce giant had struggled to gain a foothold in a society that prefers to shop in person, with cash, but now Italians are hooked on online shopping.
articles.abstract: The e-commerce giant had struggled to gain a foothold in a society that prefers to shop in person, with cash, but now Italians are hooked on online shopping.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Italy — Ludovica Tomaciello had never shopped on Amazon before being trapped at her parents’ house in March during Italy’s coronavirus lockdown. Bored one afternoon scrolling TikTok, she spotted hair scrunchies that she then tracked down and ordered on Amazon.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Emma Bubola

articles.headline: The Virus Sent Droves to a Small Town. Suddenly, It’s Not So Small.
articles.snippet: The population boomed in Winhall, Vt., as people tried to get away from Covid-19 hot spots. Bear complaints are up. Plumbers are booked until Christmas. And the dump is “sheer pandemonium.”
articles.abstract: The population boomed in Winhall, Vt., as people tried to get away from Covid-19 hot spots. Bear complaints are up. Plumbers are booked until Christmas. And the dump is “sheer pandemonium.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WINHALL, Vt. — From his post at the town dump, Scott Bushee spent the summer observing his new neighbors, transplants who pulled into his compound with heads full of rustic fantasy and license plates from New York and New Jersey.

articles.headline: Trump Announces Barrett as Supreme Court Nominee, Describing Her as Heir to Scalia
articles.snippet: In choosing Judge Amy Coney Barrett, the president opted for the candidate most likely to thrill his conservative base and outrage his liberal opponents.
articles.abstract: In choosing Judge Amy Coney Barrett, the president opted for the candidate most likely to thrill his conservative base and outrage his liberal opponents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump introduced Judge Amy Coney Barrett as his nominee to the Supreme Court on Saturday, presenting her as a champion of conservative judicial principles and igniting a partisan and ideological battle to confirm her before the election in just 38 days.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Voters Believe Winner of Election Should Fill Court Vacancy, Poll Shows
articles.snippet: A Times/Siena College poll showed that 56 percent said the next president should nominate a Supreme Court justice. And Joe Biden retained a clear lead over President Trump, 49 to 41 percent.
articles.abstract: A Times/Siena College poll showed that 56 percent said the next president should nominate a Supreme Court justice. And Joe Biden retained a clear lead over President Trump, 49 to 41 percent.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: As Covid-19 Closes Schools, the World’s Children Go to Work
articles.snippet: Former students are taking illegal and often dangerous jobs in India and other developing countries, potentially rolling back years of progress in social mobility and public health.
articles.abstract: Former students are taking illegal and often dangerous jobs in India and other developing countries, potentially rolling back years of progress in social mobility and public health.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUMAKURU, India — Every morning in front of the Devaraj Urs public housing apartment blocks on the outskirts of the city of Tumakuru, a swarm of children pours into the street.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Suhasini Raj

articles.headline: Trump’s Taxes Show Chronic Losses and Years of Income Tax Avoidance
articles.snippet: The Times obtained Donald Trump’s tax information extending over more than two decades, revealing struggling properties, vast write-offs, an audit battle and hundreds of millions in debt coming due.
articles.abstract: The Times obtained Donald Trump’s tax information extending over more than two decades, revealing struggling properties, vast write-offs, an audit battle and hundreds of millions in debt coming due.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Times obtained Donald Trump’s tax information extending over more than two decades, revealing struggling properties, vast write-offs, an audit battle and hundreds of millions in debt coming due.
articles.byline: By Russ Buettner, Susanne Craig and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Ransomware Attacks Take On New Urgency Ahead of Vote
articles.snippet: Attacks against small towns, big cities and the contractors who run their voting systems have federal officials fearing that hackers will try to sow chaos around the election.
articles.abstract: Attacks against small towns, big cities and the contractors who run their voting systems have federal officials fearing that hackers will try to sow chaos around the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Texas company that sells software that cities and states use to display results on election night was hit by ransomware last week, the latest of nearly a thousand such attacks over the past year against small towns, big cities and the contractors who run their voting systems.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Trump Wants to Discredit the Election. This Nerd Could Stop Him.
articles.snippet: Fox News, the president’s favored network, will face enormous pressure to call the election for Mr. Trump. The outcome rests on a little-known 65-year-old wonk who will declare the winner.
articles.abstract: Fox News, the president’s favored network, will face enormous pressure to call the election for Mr. Trump. The outcome rests on a little-known 65-year-old wonk who will declare the winner.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election.]

articles.headline: China’s Economy Comes Roaring Back, Led by Wealthy Consumers
articles.snippet: Big crowds at places like the Beijing auto show are a sign of good news, but China needs its less affluent to spend more before its growth engine can return to full speed.
articles.abstract: Big crowds at places like the Beijing auto show are a sign of good news, but China needs its less affluent to spend more before its growth engine can return to full speed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Right before executives and car enthusiasts could gather in Geneva for the big auto show there in early March, the organizers called it off. As the coronavirus spread, other shows followed suit: Detroit, Los Angeles, New York, Paris and São Paulo.

articles.headline: How Joe Biden Is Preparing for the Biggest Debate of His Life
articles.snippet: The first debate between Joseph R. Biden Jr. and President Trump on Tuesday represents one of the president’s last, best chances to move a race that polls show him losing. There are risks for Mr. Biden, too.
articles.abstract: The first debate between Joseph R. Biden Jr. and President Trump on Tuesday represents one of the president’s last, best chances to move a race that polls show him losing. There are risks for Mr. Biden, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election.]
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck
